data.text:
This is the first novel in the â€œHal Spacejockâ€ series, and Iâ€™m reading it second, after â€œHal Spacejock: Second Course.â€ Confused yet? Luckily, I wasnâ€™t. Simon Haynes has constructed his series in such a way that each book is a stand-alone novel; itâ€™s not at all like a fantasy epic where you have to remember endless lists of characters and places. This is a good thing. There was only one major â€˜spoilerâ€™ as a consequence of reading book #2 before book #1, but more on that later.

â€œHal Spacejockâ€ is an effortless, enjoyable read. I remember reading something Douglas Adams had written about his first â€œHitchhikerâ€™s Guide to the Galaxyâ€ novel, and it is worth retelling here. Adams said that he was aware that the book was very smooth and easy to read, but that it had taken a LOT of work to create this effect. I suspect that the same is true of Haynesâ€™ novel. The book goes down so easily because it has been crafted. This is what I especially admire about Haynesâ€™ art: you can see that he is a skilled craftsman of words.

In my review of Spacejock #2, I suggested that Haynes had found a good balance between necessary descriptive passages and humorous dialogue. The dialogue in this novel (which focuses, for the most part, on the interplay between Spacejock and the robot Clunk) is light, even breezy. Itâ€™s all mildly amusing. What impressed me this time around, however, was the sheer visceral quality of Haynesâ€™ descriptive writing. Especially in regard to Spacejockâ€™s spaceship, the Black Gull, I was impressed by the verisimilitude (howâ€™s that for a wank word?) of the setting. In short, the Black Gull felt like a real spaceship. A dirty, broken-down spaceship, but a real one nonetheless.

Reviewers of the Spacejock novels tend to mention how the series seems to owe much of its heritage to Adamsâ€™ â€œHitchhikerâ€™s Guide to the Galaxyâ€ and Grant/Naylorâ€™s â€œRed Dwarf.â€ While itâ€™s true that there are similarities (thereâ€™s one conversation between Hal and a door on the Black Gull that seems to read straight from the pages of â€œHitchhikersâ€), Haynes is no mere imitator. To me,â€The Hitchhikerâ€™s Guide to the Galaxyâ€ is a philosophical fantasy, while â€œRed Dwarfâ€ is a bawdier, low-brow romp. â€œHal Spacejockâ€ is neither philosophical nor bawdy, but it has a gritty reality that neither of the other seriesâ€™ possess.

Another interesting thing about this series is that, in its way, this is a low-tech future. Sure, there seem to be lots of spaceships whizzing around the galaxy, but thereâ€™s not a lot of virtual reality type stuff. I actually liked this aspect, and it ties in with my point about the â€˜realityâ€™ of the Black Gull. In Haynesâ€™ universe, credits are physical tokens, not cyber-money (hmmm, like Netbank?). Robots are clunky, lumbering machines, not amorphous shapeshifters. To paraphrase â€œHitchhikersâ€ again: men were real men, robots were real robots, and spaceships really need regular maintenance. This is where Iâ€™m trying to avoid going off on a rant about â€˜gimmicky future bullshitâ€™ science fiction. Okay, Iâ€™ve taken a deep breath.

The main plot of â€œHal Spacejockâ€ sees Hal in his run-down ship trying to make ends meet. Iâ€™ve read a lot of SF, but I canâ€™t remember too many novels in which the protagonist is acutely, genuinely, hard up. But Hal is skint. The main storyline sees the conniving Farrell Hinchfig trying to con Hal out of a shipment of robot parts intended for the cigar-chomping Walter Jerling. Hinchfig and his blaster-toting sidekick try to dupe Spacejock by creating a simulacrum of Jerling. Hinchfigâ€™s spaceship is called the Volante. This is where I encountered my one and only problem with reading these novels out of order. Readers of this series will know that Halâ€™s spaceship in book two is the Volante. Therefore I was instantly alerted to the fact that Hal would win the day and end up trading in his rust-bucket for the brand new Volante, probably at Farrell Hinchfigâ€™s expense. But that was a small worry. After all, I shouldnâ€™t know that Clunk would end up as Halâ€™s sidekick for the rest of the series, but as his face is on the cover of all the Spacejock novels, thatâ€™s a pretty big giveaway.

Okay, SPOILER ALERT. If you havenâ€™t read this book, and Iâ€™ve whetted your appetite for it, then you can stop now. Still here? Right. Hal ends up with a whole host of nasty problems, in the form of Brutus, the debt-collection robot, and Farrell Hinchfig and his sidekick Terry. And then of course thereâ€™s Jerling on Halâ€™s case as well. Thereâ€™s a series of shenanigans that takes place in or near an exclusive casino, and slightly before that, a very â€˜luckyâ€™ car-crash which reunites Hal and Clunk after they had been separated. Hal gets away with it in the end, of course, and thereâ€™s an elegant solution to the two sets of nasties that are on Halâ€™s tail. It all ends with a bang. And Hal ends up with the Volante, as I realised would happen. Hal, who had spent most of the book showing a blatant disregard for Clunkâ€™s welfare, suddenly develops a kind streak, and buys the robot from Jerling before stealing the now-departed Farrellâ€™s shiny spaceship. So itâ€™s a happy ending.

For a theoretically â€˜violentâ€™ book (thereâ€™s no end of gun battles and explosions), there seems to be a strain of pacifism at work in â€œHal Spacejock.â€ Hal and Clunk solve their problems through trickery and deception, rarely by brute force. This is a good message for anyone, but especially for teenagers: brains with always triumph over brawn (just ask Barry Hall ğŸ™‚ ) And so â€œHal Spacejockâ€ left me with a warm fuzzy feeling. Rarely have I read a book that was simultaneously so amusing and so warm-hearted. Humour usually revolves around laughing at the misfortune of others, but thereâ€™s precious little nastiness here. This is an excellent novel, and I would recommend it to anyone.
